Title: Engineering a chess match against my brother
Description: This is the story of me trying to win a game of chess against my brother. A single freaking game. What‚Äôs so special about it? Am I good at chess? Not at all. Did I improve at my game in the process? Also no. Is it a story about ‚Äúthe journey rather than the destination‚Äù? Not really. Did I at least have fun in the process? Not so sure. This is the story of me trying to be unconventional at probably the most studied game in existence and using my software engineering background for something that probably doesn‚Äôt need it.

Title: about sstatic.net
Description: If your domain is www.example.org, you can host your static components on static.example.org. However, if you've already set cookies on the top-level domain example.org as opposed to www.example.org, then all the requests to static.example.org will include those cookies. In this case, you can buy a whole new domain, host your static components there, and keep this domain cookie-free. Yahoo! uses yimg.com, YouTube uses ytimg.com, Amazon uses images-amazon.com and so on.

Title: A Project of One's Own
Description:
A few days ago, on the way home from school, my nine year old son
told me he couldn't wait to get home to write more of the story he
was working on. This made me as happy as anything I've heard him
say ‚Äî not just because he was excited about his story, but because
he'd discovered this way of working. Working on a project of your
own is as different from ordinary work as skating is from walking.
It's more fun, but also much more productive.

Title: Clever vs Insightful Code ‚Ä¢ Hillel Wayne
Description:
‚ÄúDon‚Äôt write clever code.‚Äù Why not? ‚ÄúBecause it‚Äôs hard to understand.‚Äù People who say this think of clever code such as Duff‚Äôs Device:



Duff's Device

send(to, from, count) register short *to, *from; register count; { register n = (count + 7) / 8; switch (count % 8) { case 0: do { *to = *from++; case 7: *to = *from++; case 6: *to = *from++; case 5: *to = *from++; case 4: *to = *from++; case 3: *to = *from++; case 2: *to = *from++; case 1: *to = *from++; } while (--n > 0); } }  
This code is ‚Äúclever‚Äù because it exploits knowledge about the language, in this case the peculiarities of fall-through.
